variant.question: During a sunny day and at the same latitude, over which of the following positions will the warming of air just above the surface be the greatest? Above..
Which typical weather situation over Central Europe is shown on the weather chart? (Spacing of the isobars 5 hPa)
Refer to a hot sunny day and consider the same latitude. Which of the following ground surfaces will warm up the air above such surface most?
An aircraft over western Europe is crossing a jet stream 2 500 ft below its core at right angles. While crossing, the outside air temperature is increasing. The prevailing wind is:
What causes low level cloud in front of the warm front?

options.text: Rain dragging warm air into the cold air and condensing it.
Cold air passing over warm surface.
Rain falling into warm air and condensing.
Warm air passing over cold surface.

variant.question:
Refer to the image.
Which aircraft is experiencing the greatest headwind, when flying close to the surface?
A warm front is approaching the destination aerodrome at approximately the same time the aircraft will make its approach. In addition to rain and low cloud, what conditions could be expected?

options.text: A narrow band of shallow fog , clearing as soon as the front passes
Fog may be encountered, clearing only slowly after the front passes
Patches of fog, but these will only form after the front has passed
Although visibility may reduce before the front arrives, it will NOT reduce below 1000 metres

variant.question: If a parcel of humid air is forced to rise from the ground during summer (1) _____ may occur and unstable conditions for (2) _____ are created.
What clouds are you likely to encounter approximately 800 km ahead of a warm front?
When a rain shower approaches and passes an airfield, the following will happen

options.text: the temperature drops and dew point rises.
the temperature rises and dew point drops.
the temperature remains unchanged and dew point drops.
the temperature rises and dew point remains unchanged.

variant.question: What is the colour with which a warm front is shown on a surface chart?
A non-occluded frontal wave passes the airport. What form of precipitation do you expect?

options.text: Continuous rain or snow during several hours until the warm front arrives. The precipitation stops for several hours or becomes intermittent light within the warm sector. On the arrival of the cold front, showers will occur.
Continuous rain or snow while the frontal wave passes for a period of some 24 hours.
Showers during a few hours until the warm front arrives. Drizzle in the warm sector. Continuous rain or snow on the passage of the cold front.
Rain or snow for about 12 hours until the warm front arrives. Within the warm sector rainfall increases. On the arrival of the cold front precipitation ceases.

variant.question:
(Refer to image)   
At Lyon (LFLY, N4545 E00500), at 1200 UTC, the sky is overcast with Stratocumulus and Altostratus and it is raining. Using the SWC in appendix, valid at 1200 UTC, we can estimate a weather improvement for Lyon at:
At a station at the surface the significant weather with a warm front will come:

options.text: after the warm sector has passed.
only at the same time as the front passes.

variant.question: The weather most likely to predominate in an area affected as a warm front passes is

options.text: moderate continuous rain, intermittent light drizzle.

variant.question: Regarding thermodynamic stability and ground visibility, what are the differences between a warm air mass and a cold air mass in Central Europe during summer?

options.text: The cold air mass is unstable and the visibility is better than in the warm air mass.
The cold air mass is unstable and the visibility is worse than in the warm air mass.
The cold air mass is stable and the visibility is better than in the warm air mass.
The warm air mass is stable and the visibility is better than in the cold air mass.

variant.question: Define a warm front

options.text: the situation when warm air displaces cold air.
the front side of a heat wave.
the situation when cold air displaces warm air.

options.text: the cold air behind is warmer than the cold air ahead.
the cold air ahead is lifted.
the cold air behind is lifted by the warm air.
the cold air behind is colder than the cold air ahead.

variant.question: An occlusion has the characteristics of a warm front when:

options.text: the cold air behind is warmer than the cold air ahead
the cold air behind is colder than the cold air ahead
the cold air behind is lifted by the warm air
the cold air ahead is lifted

variant.question: What types of cloud will you see flying at FL 50 towards a warm front?

options.text: At some 800 km CS, later AS, and at some 300 km NS until the front
At some 500 km from the front, groups of CB, later at some 250 km thickening AS
Mainly clear skies. At some 100 km from the front NS begins
At some 500 km AS, later CS and at some 80 km before the front CB

variant.question:
Refer to figure 050-20.
For an aircraft making an approach to an airfield which is not situated near high ground, in the vicinity of the active front in square 3B, a potential hazard exists in the form of:
Which weather development has to be expected by a pilot who flies from the East towards a stable warm front which is approaching from the West?

options.text: At approximately 800 km ahead of the surface front there is overcast cirrostratus, the cloudbase lowers to become a typical overcast altostratus and finally a nimbostratus. At approximately 300km ahead of the surface front the aurcraft encounters rain which intensifies.

At approximately 1000 km ahead of the surface front there is overcast cirrostratus, the cloudbase lowers to become a typical overcast altostratus and finally a nimbostratus. At approximately 300km ahead of the surface front the aurcraft encounters rain which intensifies.

Flying towards the surface front, the aircraft suddenly encounters an area with a low cloud ceiling and rain, then conditions improve on the course to the West until the rain finally ceases. The cloud ceiling rises slowly, at a distance of approximately 800 km from the surface front, the sky clears.

At approximately 500 km ahead of the surface front there is overcast cirrostratus, the cloudbase lowers to become a typical overcast altostratus and finally a nimbostratus. At approximately 300km ahead of the surface front the aurcraft encounters rain which intensifies.

variant.question: Which weather development has to be expected by a pilot who flies from the East towards a stable warm front which is approaching from the West?

options.text: At approximately 800 km ahead of the surface front there is overcast cirrostratus the cloud base lowers to become a typical overcast altostratus and finally a nimbostratus. At approximately 300 km ahead of the surface front, the aircraft encounters rain which intensifies.

At approximately 500 km ahead of the surface front there is overcast cirrostratus the cloud base lowers to become a typical overcast altostratus and finally a nimbostratus. At approximately 300 km ahead of the surface front, the aircraft encounters rain which intensifies.

Flying towards the surface front, the aircraft suddenly encounters an area with a low cloud ceiling and rain, then conditions improve on the course to the West until the rain finally ceases. The cloud ceiling rises slowly, at a distance of approximately 800 km from the surface front, the sky clears.

At approximately 1000 km ahead of the surface front there is overcast cirrostratus the cloud base lowers to become a typical overcast altostratus and finally a nimbostratus. At approximately 300 km ahead of the surface front, the aircraft encounters rain which intensifies.

a fall in temperature, rise in dew point temperature, wind backing and decreasing.
a rise in temperature, a rapid rise in pressure, wind backs and becomes gusty.
a rapid improvement in visibility, pressure falling rapidly, the wind veering and increasing.

options.text: a rise in temperature, a rise in dew point temperature, wind veers and increases
a rapid improvement in visibility, pressure falling rapidly, wind veering and increasing
a decrease in temperature, a rise in dew point temperature, wind backing and decreasing
a rise in temperature, a rapid rise in pressure, wind backs and becomes gusty

winds back and increase with height.
winds veer and decrease with height.
winds back and decrease with height.

High cloud base, good surface visibility, and isolated thunderstorms.

variant.question: The speed of a warm front is...

The speed found by measuring the distance between the isobars along the front itself.

air ahead of the occlusion being warmer than the air behind the occlusion.

cold air is moist and the environmental lapse rate exceeds the saturated adiabatic lapse rate
cold air is moist and the environmental lapse rate is less than the dry adiabatic lapse rate

variant.question:
A pilot will depart from ESSA airport. During the briefing the meteorologist informs him/her that there is strong instability in the area and presents the following special weather report.
SPECI ESSA 31035G45KT 270V360 3000 BKNO10CB BKNO23TCU OVC040 24/20 Q0990 RERA WS.

options.text: could form because of the existent circular air motion and the prevailing low pressure.
could NOT form because dry and dusty ground is NOT existent in the area.
could form because the air temperature is close to the dew point.
could NOT form because the OAT is below 26°C which is the temperature at which a tornado could form.
